questions.text: A 25-year-old artist visits an art gallery. A painting of checkered squares appears distorted only to him, as shown below. He decides to go see an ophthalmologist who after initial evaluation, suggests an FFA. The FFA  shows a characteristic smoke stack appearance. Breakdown of which of the following barriers is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a characteristic smoke stack pattern on FFA is suggestive of a diagnosis of central serous retinopathy. In CSR, the outer blood-retinal barrier is disrupted.

CSR is the serous detachment of the neurosensory retina with focal and multifocal areas of leakage at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), mainly affecting the macular area. That is why the patient who is usually a young male presents with macular symptoms such as blurring of central vision, metamorphopsia.

The blood-retina barrier (BRB) is composed of inner and outer barriers. The outer BRB refers to the barrier formed at the retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cell layer and regulates the movement of solutes and nutrients from the choroid to the sub-retinal space. By contrast, the inner BRB, similar to the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is located in the inner retinal microvasculature and comprises the microvascular endothelium, which lines these vessels.

The image given below shows the smoke-stack pattern seen in CSR.

Amsler grid is used in detecting maculopathy.

Uses:

  • Assess macular function
  • Evaluate the visual field of 10°
  • Good for follow-up in CSR

The image below shows Amsler's grid.

questions.text: Where does fluid accumulate in central serous retinopathy?

choices.text: Between the Bruch membrane and retinal pigment epithelium
Between the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer

questions.solution:
Fluid accumulation in central serous retinopathy (CSR) is in the subretinal space due to abnormal permeability of the choriocapillaris.

The image depicts optical coherence tomography showing fluid accumulation in the subretinal space, with shallow retinal detachment.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with acute loss of vision and metamorphopsia. There is a history of the positive scotoma. Fundal changes are given below. What will be the fundus fluorescein angiography finding?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the fundal image depicting focal fundal detachment are suggestive of central serous retinopathy. An enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern is seen in FFA.

Central serous retinopathy refers to the spontaneous serous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region. Recent studies implicate an abnormal choroidal circulation as the cause of CSR. 

Clinical features:

  • Retinal detachment - Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Relative positive scotoma
  • Micropsia
  • Metamorphopsia

Investigations:

  • Ophthalmoscopy - circular ring reflex present and foveal reflex absent
  • FFA - enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern

Spontaneous resolution is seen in most cases and hence observation is enough. Steroids are contraindicated. The disease is usually self-limiting but may recur.

The image depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/enlarging dot sign, which is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

Other options:

Option B- Petaloid appearance is seen in cystoid macular edema

Option C- Stars in the sky appearance is suggestive of drusen

Option D- Dual circulation is a pathognomonic feature of choroidal melanoma

questions.text: A 69-year-old man who is a chronic smoker, hypertensive, and has a BMI of 35 kg/m2 complains of diminished vision in the right eye. His visual acuity is 6/36 BE and the anterior segment appears normal. His fundus is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the image which shows drusen (druplets) are a feature of dry or non-exudative age-related macular degeneration (ARMD). 

Drusen are the earliest visible clinical signs of ARMD. They are composed of lipid, amyloid, complement factors, and associated cellular components.

There are two types of ARMD:

  • Dry (non-exudative, non-neovascular) ARMD is the most common form, comprising around 90% of the diagnosed cases. Initially characterized by macular Drusens, which later progress to geographical atrophy. Geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry ARMD. Antioxidants like the AREDS2 supplements have proven effective.
  • Wet (exudative, neovascular) ARMD is much less common than the dry type, but it is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss.

Clinical classification:

Definition

(based on the presence of lesions within two disc diameters of the fovea in either eye)

age-related changes		 No drusen

questions.text:
Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA) is primarily indicated in which of the following conditions?

CNVM - choroidal neovascular membrane
questions.solution:
Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA) is primarily indicated in an occult choroidal neovascular membrane (CNVM).

ICGA is used to visualize the choroidal vasculature. 

Its main use is to differentiate between classic and occult CNVM when the clinical picture is not clear.

questions.text:
Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF is used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?

ARMD - age-related macular degeneration
questions.solution:
Intravitreal injection of anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is used as the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration (ARMD).

Wet ARMD is characterized by retinal pigment epithelial detachment and choroidal/subretinal neovascularization.

Treatment of ARMD depends on the location of the choroidal neovascularization membrane:

  • For extrafoveal membrane - Laser photocoagulation
  • For subfoveal and juxta foveal membranes, treatment options are as follows:
    • Intravitreal injection of anti -VEGF agents
    • Photodynamic therapy - the dye used is verteporfin followed by exposure to light from a diode
    • Transpupillary thermotherapy

RGX-314 is an anti-VEGF treatment delivered by gene therapy. It has the potential to block VEGF for years following a surgical procedure in which a harmless virus, called adeno-associated virus (AAV), carrying the anti-VEGF gene, is injected under the retina. This method is still under the trial.

questions.text: An old cab driver whose livelihood depends on his driving is distressed. He complains that everything appears distorted and he perceives objects to smaller than their usual size. His anterior segment appears normal. Examination of the fundus reveals a honeycomb appearance of the macula. FFA is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is that of fluorescein angiography showing the "flower petal pattern," which is seen in cystoid macular edema (CME). The characteristic flower-petal appearance is due to the accumulation of dye in the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer at the macula

The accumulation of fluid in the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer leads to retinal thickening at macula and loss of foveal depression, formation of cystic spaces (honey-comb macula). Risk factors include retinitis pigmentosa, uveitis, niacin, PGE2 analogues, epinephrine in aphakia, diabetic retinopathy, retinal venous occlusion and Irvin-Gass syndrome (CME post-cataract surgery).

Symptoms may include blurring of vision, distortion, and micropsia.

Therapeutic approaches for treating CME depend on the underlying etiology. This includes steroids, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, anti-VEGF agents, PPV for associated vitreomacular traction.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department and is found to have a corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, corneal perforation, and foreign body. Which of the following will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Suprachoroidal hemorrhage will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient.

Maculopathy is common in eyes developing hypotony, which is defined as IOP <6 mmHg. The most common cause is excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery (Option D). Other causes include trauma such as cyclodialysis of the uvea (Option B), penetrating injury (Option C), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment, and other systemic causes such as dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes, uremia, and treatment with hyperosmotic agents. They usually cause bilateral hypotonic maculopathy.

Suprachoroidal hemorrhage is a bleed into the suprachoroidal space that results from the rupture of the posterior ciliary artery. When the bleed is severe it causes extrusion of intraocular contents that is termed as expulsive hemorrhage. It is a rare but dreaded complication of the phacoemulsification procedure. Signs seen in suprachoroidal hemorrhage are:

  • Progressive increase in intraocular pressure
  • Prolapse of iris
  • Loss or partial obscuration of the red reflex
  • In severe cases there can be extrusion of the posterior segment contents into the anterior chamber and through the incision such as vitreous extrusion

Immediate treatment involves rapid closure of the incision followed by administration of IOP-lowering medications such as oral acetazolamide and topical or systemic steroids to reduce inflammation. Standard post-operative antibiotics can be added in these patients.

questions.text: A 45-year old patient on systemic treatment for rheumatoid arthritis develops bilateral painless decrease in vision. What does the image show?

choices.text: Fluorescein angiography showing bull’s eye maculopathy
Autofluorescence showing changes of bull’s eye maculopathy

questions.solution:
The investigation shown in the image is an autofluorescence showing bull’s eye maculopathy.

Hydroxychloroquine, which is generally used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, toxicity causes bull’s eye maculopathy. Chloroquine binds to melanin in the retinal pigment epithelium, causing cytotoxic effects. RPE atrophy occurs in the macula, resulting in dark areas on the autofluorescence image.

Other causes of Bull’s eye maculopathy include chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine, congenital cone dystrophy, juvenile X-linked retinoschisis, and juvenile Batten's disease.

Fundus autofluorescence is a non-invasive imaging modality. It reflects the morphological changes associated with the metabolism of lipofuscin and does not require the injection of any fluorescent dye.

A fundus image of bull’s eye maculopathy is shown below:

The following image shows the difference between fundus autofluorescence and fluorescence angiography

Other ocular effects of chloroquine include:

  • Chloroquine keratopathy—vortex keratopathy
  • Ocular palsy, ptosis
  • Electroretinographic depression
  • Optic neuritis
  • Posterior subcapsular cataract

questions.text: A study used electroretinography(ERG) in military conscripts whose visual abnormalities could not be explained by the findings of ophthalmologic, neurological, and psychiatric examinations. The ERG of pure malingerers was found to be, as shown below. The activity of which cells of the retina is depicted by the a-wave?
questions.solution:
"a" wave in an electroretinogram (ERG) represents rods and cones.

Electroretinography is used to evaluate retinal functions by examining the electrical response to a light stimulus.

Electroretinograms (ERGs) show the amplitudes of currents that flow within the eye following exposure to a point of light. The amplitudes are analyzed into waves, which are composed of the responses of neuronal, glial, and retinal pigment epithelial cells.

ERG:

  • The a-wave originates from photoreceptors (rods and cones)
  • The b-wave originates from Muller and bipolar cells, but is directly dependant on photoreceptors
  • The c-wave originates from retinal pigment epithelial cells and retinal glial cells
  • Oscillatory potentials (OPs) originate in the inner retina

Scotopic ERGs are used to evaluate responses starting from rod photoreceptors exposed to flash-light in darkness, and photopic ERGs are used to evaluate responses starting from cone photoreceptors exposed to flash-light under constant light exposure.

questions.text: Which area of the retina has the highest concentration of rods?
questions.solution:
Mid-periphery of the retina has the highest concentration of rods.

The following table lists the differences between rods and cones

Property Rods Cones
Number Most numerous (120 million) Far fewer in number (6 million)
Location Mid-peripheral retina Fovea
Function
  • Night vision
  • Motion sense
  • Peripheral vision
  • Day vision
  • Colour vision
  • Central and fine vision
Dysfunction symptoms
  • Nyctalopia
  • Peripheral field loss
  • Poor central vision
  • Dyschromatopsia
  • Hemeralopia

questions.text: A researcher is studying mutations in the rhodopsin gene which are responsible for some forms of autosomal dominant retinitis pigmentosa. On which chromosome is this gene located?
questions.solution:
The gene for rhodopsin is located at 3q22.1

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common. Among the hereditary types, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations:

  • Perimetry - the initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography - reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

Retinitis pigmentosa is a condition with no cure. There are drugs used to slow down the progression such as acetazolamide for concomitant cystoid macular edema. Recently, vitamin A has been recommended, although the efficacy has not been established.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)?

choices.text: RPE forms the inner blood retinal barrier
Electroculogram is an assessment of RPE health
Bruch’s membrane is the basement membrane of RPE

questions.solution:
Tight junctions between retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) form the outer blood-retinal barrier. The inner blood-retinal barrier is formed by the tight junctions between the endothelial cells of retinal capillaries.

RPE serves many functions, like

  • Development of photoreceptors during embryogenesis
  • Tight junctions between RPE form the outer blood-retinal barrier
  • Absorption of fluid from the subretinal space and adhesion of the underlying neurosensory retina
  • Selective transport of metabolites to and from the retina
  • Uptake, transport, storage, metabolism, and isomerization of vitamin A
  • Regeneration of the visual pigment rhodopsin
  • Phagocytosis of photoreceptor outer segment tips
  • Absorption of stray light by melanin

If the RPE is damaged, this is seen as a loss of autofluorescence (RPE-deficient areas appear darker on autofluorescence images).

Bruch's membrane is the basement membrane of RPE.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is not associated with retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is associated with abetalipoprotenemia (Bassen–Kornzweig syndrome) and not with abetaglobulinemia.

 

Syndromes associated with RP (Atypical RP)
Usher syndrome  Sensory neural deafness + RP 

Bardet–Biedl syndrome 

(Previously called Lawrence–Moon–Biedl–Bartum Syndrome)

 Polydactyly, obesity, mental handicap, and kidney disease + RP
Kearn–Sayre syndrome Ocular myopathy and heart disease + RP
Refsum Syndrome   

Varied skin as well as neurological and visceral features + RP
 

Bassen–Kornzweig syndrome

 Abetalipoprotenemia and acanthocytosis + RP
Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP) Neuropathy and Ataxia + RP

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
Electroretinogram (ERG) is abnormal in retinitis pigmentosa (RP).

ERG is a sensitive diagnostic test in retinitis pigmentosa that shows reduced scotopic, subnormal responses in early disease and becomes completely extinguished in advanced disease. Electroocoulogram (EOG) is also abnormal in retinitis pigmentosa.

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is an inherited or acquired pigmentatory retinal dystrophy affecting the rods more than the cones. The earliest manifestation is worsening of night blindness and delayed adaptation which gradually progresses to tunnel vision and ultimately loss of central vision.

The classic triad of findings in RP comprises:

  1. Bone-spicule retinal pigmentation
  2. Arteriolar attenuation
  3. ‘Waxy’ disc pallor

The image below shows the classical triad findings of retinitis pigmentosa.

Systemic associations of RP include:

  • Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome -retinitis pigmentosa, obesity, hypogenitalism,polydactyly and mental deficiency
  • Cockayne's syndrome-retinitis pigmentosa,infantile deafness, dwarfism, mental retardation and ataxia
  • Refsum's syndrome-retinitis pigmemosa, peripheral neuropathy and cerebellar ataxia
  • Usher's syndrome
  • Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome

The Argus II Retinal prosthesis also called the "artificial retina" has been approved to treat adults with severe to profound retinitis pigmentosa. The device is designed to replicate the function of photoreceptors in converting visual information into electrical neural signals. There are no other satisfactory treatment for retinitis pigmentosa.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The fundus shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries, and bony spicules, which implies retinitis pigmentosa (RP).  

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common. Among the hereditary type, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations:

  • Perimetry - the initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography - reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

Atypical types of RP are as follows:

  • Sectoral RP
  • Pericentric/Inverse RP
  • RP sine pigmento
  • RP punctata albescens

There is no effective treatment for RP.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the Mizuo phenomenon seen?
questions.solution:
Mizuo phenomenon is seen in Oguchi's disease.

Oguchi's disease is a type of congenital stationary night blindness with abnormal fundus. Congenital stationary night blindness refers to a group of disorders characterized by infantile-onset nyctalopia but non-progressive retinal dysfunction. The fundus has an unusual golden yellow color in the light-adapted state, which becomes normal after prolonged dark adaptation (Mizuo or Mizuo–Nakamura phenomenon).

The following image shows a comparison in the fundus appearances ("A" shows the golden yellow color of the fundus in a light-adapted state; "B" shows normal-appearing funds after prolonged dark adaptation of 3 to 4 hours)

Rod function is absent even after 30 minutes of dark adaptation (normal dark adaptation time is 20–30 mins) but recovers to a near-normal level after a long period of dark adaptation (4 hours).

questions.text: Flat electrooculogram (EOG) is an Arden ratio of _______.
questions.solution:
A flat electrooculogram (EOG) is an Arden ratio of less than 1.25.

An EOG measures the standing potential of the eye. It reflects the activity of the RPE and the photoreceptors. This means that an eye blinded by disease proximal to the photoreceptors will have a normal EOG. Arden ratio is the ratio between the light peak and the dark trough in an EOG.

The normal Arden ratio is 1.85 and above. A flat EOG occurs when the Arden ratio is less than 1.25.

Best disease is an autosomal-dominant childhood disease characterized by the dystrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium. In Best disease, the Arden ratio is less than 1.50.

questions.text: A young patient presents with loss of central vision. ERG is normal, but EOG is abnormal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the above scenario is Best's disease.

Best's disease/Vitelliform macular dystrophy is an inherited macular dystrophy in which lipofuscin accumulates in the central macula causing progressive central vision loss. It is autosomal-dominant and linked to the mutation in the bestrophin (VMD2) gene.

It is characterized by bilateral yellow, yolk-like (vitelliform) macular lesions.

The stages of evolution of the macular lesions are described as progressing from:

  • Pre-vitelliform stage
  • Vitelliform stage - scrambled egg stage with or without hypopyon
  • Vitelliruptive - the lesion breaks and visual acuity drops
  • The atrophic stage

Patients with Best’s disease usually have good visual acuity when the "yolk" remains intact.

Diagnosis: This is the only disease with relatively normal ERG results associated with an abnormal EOG. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) reveals that the vitelliform material appears as a dome-shaped, hyperreflective, and homogenous lesion, located below the hyperreflective photoreceptor layer.

The image below shows Best’s disease - the typical vitelliform lesion in an 11-year-old girl.

questions.text: A young patient presents with loss of central vision. There is a family history of a similar condition. Both EOG and ERG are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given scenario is Stargardt's disease.

Stargardt's disease also known as Stargardt macular dystrophy or fundus flavimaculatus is the most common macular dystrophy. It most commonly is inherited in an autosomal-recessive manner caused by a mutation on an adenosine triphosphate-binding cassette (ABCA4) gene.

Characterized by macular "pisciform" flecks that accumulate at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), sometimes resulting in central macular atrophy early in life. Patients develop a macula with a “beaten bronze” appearance caused by atrophic changes in the RPE. In addition, a "dark" or "silent" choroid is seen on the fluorescein angiography that appears as a prominent retinal circulation against hypofluorescent choroid. 

The electroretinogram (ERG) and electro-oculography (EOG) are normal early in the disease but may be reduced in more advanced cases. Of note, the ERG findings do not directly correlate with clinical findings.

There is no known proven treatment for this disease. Because ABCA4 plays a role in vitamin A processing in the visual cycle, additional vitamin A is suspected to make the disease worse.

The image below shows macular pisciform flecks.

Other options: 

Option A: Retinitis pigmentosa: abnormal electroretinogram (ERG).

Option B: Rod–cone dystrophy: abnormal ERG.

Option D: Best's disease: Normal ERG with abnormal electrooculogram (EOG).

questions.text: Silent choroid on FFA is a feature of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Silent/Dark choroid on FFA is a feature of Stargardt's disease. The classic feature of 'silent choroid' is due to the masking of background choroidal fluorescence by lipofuscin deposits in the subretinal space.

Stargardt disease constitutes the most common type of macular dystrophy. It has mutations in a photoreceptor cell-specific ATP-binding cassette gene (ABC4) that is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. The disease usually starts in the juvenile group with progressive central vision loss and color vision loss that occurs due to the atrophy of the macular retinal pigment epithelium with an accumulation of discrete pisciform flecks of lipofuscin.

Signs of Stargardt’s disease:

  • Beaten bronze appearance of the macula that is caused by the atrophic changes in the RPE.
  • Silent/Dark choroid on FFA.
  • Visual field testing shows central vision loss.
  • The electroretinogram (ERG) is normal early in the disease but may be reduced in more advanced cases.

Fundus flavimaculatus is genetically considered to be a part of the same spectrum as Stargardt's disease with late onset i.e. usually after 40 years of age.

Other options:

Option B: Best's disease also known as vitelliform macular dystrophy is an autosomal dominant macular dystrophy in which lipofuscin accumulates in the central macula, causing progressive central vision loss. This disease is linked to mutations in the bestrophin (VMD2) gene and they do not exhibit silent choroid on FFA. Findings seen in Best’s disease are:

  • Vitelliform(yolk like) appearance of the fundus
  • Relatively normal ERG results associated with abnormal EOG

The given below is the fundus picture of Best's disease showing an egg yolk lesion in the macula.

 

Option C: Age related Macular degeneration(ARMD) also known as senile macular degeneration is a chronic and progressive bilateral degenerative disorder of the macula that affects older individuals >50 yrs. ARMD is classified as dry and wet ARMD where the hallmarks are the presence of drusen and choroidal neovascularization respectively. Drusen are extracellular eosinophilic deposits between RPE and Bruch’s membrane.

Clinical features include loss of central vision, distorted vision (lines seen as wavy), and sudden painless loss of vision as seen in wet ARMD. The image below shows Drusens in the macular area in dry macular degeneration.

Option D: Cystoid Macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina following a break in the blood-retinal barrier. In CME on fundoscopy, a honeycomb appearance and on FFA flower petal pattern can be seen. The below image shows the flower petal pattern on FFA as seen in CME.

questions.text: A neonate with leukocoria and strabismus is diagnosed to have persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV). Which of the following congenital disorders is it associated with?
questions.solution:
Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is associated with Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13).

PHPV is a developmental disorder of the vitreous humor. In this condition, there is persistence of the embryonic hyaloid vessel. 

  • Anterior PHPV - Here, the remnant vessel is attached to the back of the lens but does not reach the optic nerve. 
  • Posterior PHPV- In this form of the disease, the vessel arises from the optic nerve. 

Clinically, PHPV presents with leucocoria and microphthalmia, and there can be complications such as tractional retinal detachments. 

This condition has a poor prognosis regardless of the time of intervention.

questions.text: When compared to blood, vitreous humor has a high concentration of which of the following?
questions.solution:
When compared to blood, vitreous humor has a high concentration of ascorbate. The vitreous: plasma ratio of ascorbic acid concentration is 9:1.

This high concentration of ascorbic acid is maintained by the active transport by the ciliary body epithelium, and it is attributed to the ability of the ascorbate to absorb ultraviolet rays and act as a free radical scavenger.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman complains of discomfort in her left eye. There is a past history of blunt trauma in her childhood which made her left eye blind. Slit-lamp examination of her left eye is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
These are synchysis scintillans, which are floaters composed of cholesterol bodies, found in the vitreous (extending into the anterior chamber in this picture).

Synchysis scintillans are vitreous opacities that occur as a consequence of chronic vitreous haemorrhage, often in a blind eye. This condition is usually discovered, when frank haemorrhage is no longer present. They are composed of cholesterol derived from plasma cells or degraded products of erythrocytes.

Vitreous opacities can be caused by a variety of pathological processes and the following are few examples of vitreous opacities:

  • Vitreous haemorrhage
  • Asteroid hyalosis
  • Synchysis scintillans
  • Amyloidosis
  • Vitreous cyst
  • Persistent fetal vasculature.

questions.text: A slit-lamp examination reveals the following finding. It is also noted that these yellow-white vitreous opacities do not settle down when the eye is immobile. All of the following statements about this condition are true except:
questions.solution:
The examination findings are suggestive of asteroid bodies/hyalosis. It is not common in myopes.

Asteroid hyalosis is a common degenerative process in which calcium pyrophosphate particles collect within the vitreous gel. It is seen clinically as numerous tiny round yellow-white opacities of varying size and density. These move with the vitreous during eye movements but do not sediment inferiorly when the eye is immobile.

Only one eye is affected in 75% of patients; it rarely causes visual problems and the majority of patients are asymptomatic. The cause of asteroid hyalosis is unknown, but it has been associated with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. The prevalence of asteroid hyalosis increases with age and affects 3% of those aged 75–86 years. It is more common in men than in women. While treatment of asteroid hyalosis is usually unnecessary, vitrectomy may occasionally be indicated.

questions.text: A young male presents with recurrent vitreous hemorrhage. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
For a young male presenting with recurrent vitreous hemorrhage, the diagnosis is Eale's disease.

Eales disease is an idiopathic occlusive peripheral periphlebitis. It is characterized by three overlapping stages: inflammatory, occlusive, and retinal neovascular. Visual prognosis is good in the majority of cases. It is an important cause of visual morbidity in young males from the Indian subcontinent.

Diagnosis:

  • Symptoms - Floaters or sudden visual reduction due to vitreous hemorrhage. There can be neurological deficits as well. 
  • Mild anterior uveitis
  • Fundus - The condition is typically bilateral, although often asymmetrical.
    • Peripheral periphlebitis
    • Branch retinal vein occlusion
    • Peripheral capillary non-perfusion; microaneurysms, tortuosity, vascular shunts, and neovascularization with recurrent vitreous hemorrhage

Treatment:

  • Steroids: Periocular, systemic, topical, and intravitreal steroids seem to be helpful in the inflammatory stage.
  • Antitubercular treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic of Eale’s disease?
questions.solution:
Eale’s disease is an idiopathic inflammatory venous occlusion (phlebitis) that primarily affects the peripheral retina that is periphlebitis and is characterized by recurrent bilateral vitreous hemorrhage.

Superficial retinal hemorrhages and cotton-wool spots can be sometimes seen, but they are not characteristic of Eales disease.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of a vitreous hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for vitreous hemorrhage is ultrasonography (USG) B-scan. Mild hemorrhage causes sudden onset floaters and diffuse blurring of vision, but may not affect visual acuity, whilst a dense bleed may result in sudden painless loss of vision. 

B-mode ultrasonography(B-scan) in unclotted vitreous hemorrhage generally shows a uniform appearance, and once cellular aggregates develop, small particulate echoes become visible.

Causes of vitreous hemorrhage:

  • Acute posterior vitreous detachment associated either with a retinal tear or avulsion of a peripheral vessel
  • Proliferative retinopathy
    • Diabetic
    • Retinal vein occlusion
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Eales disease
    • Vasculitis
  • Miscellaneous retinal disorders
    • Macroaneurysm
    • Telangiectasia
    • Capillary hemangioma
  • Trauma
  • Systemic
    • Bleeding disorders
    • Terson syndrome- refers to the combination of intraocular and subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to aneurysmal rupture, most commonly arising from the anterior communicating artery.

Treatment is dictated by severity and cause, but an increasingly low threshold is being adopted for early vitrectomy.

questions.text: Sub-hyaloid hemorrhage is _______.
questions.solution:
Sub-hyaloid hemorrhage is dome-shaped or boat-shaped.

Subhyaloid hemorrhage is the collection of blood in the potential space between the posterior vitreous and internal limiting membrane of the retina.

questions.text: What is a reverse hypopyon?

choices.text: Collection of pus in the vitreous
Collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber

questions.solution:
Reverse hypopyon is the collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber.

Silicone oil is the vitreous substitute that is injected into the vitreous cavity after vitrectomy. When it gets emulsified, it enters the anterior chamber and collects in the upper part.

Complications of silicone oil in the anterior chamber:

  1. Glaucoma
  2. Band-shaped keratopathy

questions.text: Which anti-fungal can be administered intravitreally?
questions.solution:
Voriconazole and amphotericin-B can be given intravitreally.

Vancomycin and ceftazidime is the preferred combination for endophthalmitis (intravitreous). Amikacin (0.4 mg in 0.1 ml) or gentamicin (0.4 mg in 0.1 ml) are used less frequently in endophthalmitis owing to the risk of macular infarction.
